title: OAR Kit Chassis Parts for smaller Bed 3D Printer

description.text:
Two parts for the Main Chassis for the Open Academic Robot Kit. You will need to print out 2 of each and then connect these as opposites and add the the bash plate to help make the main chassis.

Updated model files include holes for the Arm and Raspberry Pi

Hi,
You will need to print off 4 of these parts, 2 left hand and 2 right handed. These will then interlock together to allow you to construct the main chassis. Laser cutting or cutting the bash guard using a bandsaw with the mounting holes around the edges will allow you to align and screw together.

UPDATE:
The holes on the main parts align with the associated Arm (to follow soon) and to mount the Raspberry Pi control module. I have also included a DXF orthographic view of the buggy without the arm to help layout.

You will notice a lot more stiffness if you add the bash guard. I have included some mounting holes for the Raspberry Pi and the Open CM board on the bash guard, if you intend to use these products in the construction of the Open Academic Robot.

author: jon_bondy

description.text:
Dedicated to the post Millenium La Pavoni portafilters.
Also works perfectly with the ROK portafilter.

60mm inner diameter.
Use as much infill as possible.

A protective cover for thin Dremel and similar cut-off grinding wheels.

Update
I did a remix http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1010900

Update 9-15
Another remix. This one has a screw-on cap.
It's probably finished but is marked a "Work in Progress" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1036486

Dremel cut-off wheels are fragile. Without protection they tend to get broken.

I break more of these wheels when they are sitting idle than I do while working with them. So I made this protective cover several months ago and, so far, so good. I just toss it in the box with the rest of the tool bits.

Tried different cover configurations, like slipping it on sideways, but this seems best. There's less chance of accidentally snapping the disk when applying or removing the cover.

It fits a 0.175 inch (4.45mm) diameter (upper-shank) mandrel. This mandrel might be a cheap knock-off or a genuine Dremel part, but I'm not sure where I got it.

Whatever the case, the mandrel should be a smooth, gentle snap-fit into the hole. The design had zero-clearance and, thanks to plastic shrinkage, the fit was perfect. Slight scaling up or down may be required for other mandrel diameters.

It's a small print so recommend printing with thin layers, slow speed plus fan cooling for the best dimensional accuracy.

24 minutes, 4 grams ABS on an Afinia.

Metric file included.

The layer by layer printing process can't create the hook part,  because there is no support for part of the hook and the slicing program flattens it out.  Printing it upside down would work but it wil probably fall over due to the lack of support.

comments.text: a good tip is if you can, print the part that holds on to the printer in pla as it is large and wont flex, but do print the part that holds the filament in abs as  if u can see in the pic I broke the long tubes and covered then in tape to work still, printing in abs should be fine and possible little Amount if warping, but abs is more flexible so the "pegs" wont snap when you insert the spool holder into the spool hole.

hey guys, this is just a gantry clip for your m3d micro printer,,, this is the same as the one that comes when you buy the printer and this is if you loose them and/or you have to transport your m3d printer and want to do it safely,

for best results have the quality on medium-high
have fill density at medium or full
don't change size as it is perfect fit for printer,,,
to attatch just open the little notifications triangle thing at the bottom left and right click the m3d icon, click out of it and the spooler will appear,, open the menu where you can change the position of the extruder and make it so the extruder is as far forward and as low as possible, then attach and if you don't know then just search up m3d printer unboxing to see people remove the gantry clips so you see how they were positioned.

comments.text: I know it looks weird but I forgot to add,,,,  for the settings has medium or high fill AND quality, and have NO RAFT!!!  and obviously without a raft ENABLE WAVE BONDING!!!!   this file is two gantry clips so just print one and it should be easy to separate if not already separated on print.

title: Alignment microscope for drilling 3D printer nozzles.

description.text:
I normally drill a nozzle by setting it up on some form of holder in a drill press and carefully adjusting the position, repeatedly inspecting from two positions at right angles to each other. As I have a lot of nozzles to drill, I felt the need for some visual aid which would allow both views to be seen simultaneously. Fortunately 3D printing let me build a device very quickly - and the ready availability of cheap USB microscopes didn't hurt at all.

Pictures included show the device in use and a view on a 0.3mm nozzle being drilled. The video at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VAD2t55Z7XI&feature=youtu.be shows the drill bit being moved first only in X and then in Y before drilling

Print mirror holders and clamp at 100%, body with 3 shells and 25% infill. The screw holes were intended to take brass inserts but 4mm PVC tubing can be superglued in. Mirrors were cut from 3mm mirror glass

comments.text: very slick, good job, love the milling skills
comments.author: stumphopper

comments.text: While I can see the desire to be precise, what the benefit to drilling the nozzle in the exact center?
comments.author: cyclone

comments.text:
The main reason for getting the nozzle hole precisely in the center is so that it meets the conical chamfer of the inside of the nozzle. This helps with the flow of material through the nozzle and removes places where material from a previous print can hide. A second reason is to make the hole as close to center of the plateau on the front of the nozzle as possible so that plastic is laid exactly the same in each direction.
Having said that, the printer that I am building at the moment has 5 extruders. The X and Y (and Z) offset variables should be less than 1mm as each nozzle is moved into the datum position - similar to tool changing in a CNC milling machine.
comments.author: cyclone

comments.text:
Pretty damn slick!
But I'd just make a plate that the nozzle screws into and can be bolted to the table.
Then chuck up the nozzle, already screwed into the plate, and then lower the press and bolt plate to table. All on center.

title: Printrbot Bed Adjuster Knob for 4mm Bolts

description.text: I had problems with my bed vibrating a lot on my Printrbot Plus V2, so I increased the bolt size, spring size, changed the nut to a standoff and created a nice knob to use in place of the wood knobs.  Works fantastic now, all vibrations are totally gone in the bed.

First, print off the adjuster knob.  
Second, at a local hardware store, I purchased new standoffs instead of standard nuts, this allows for a longer mating surface to the bolt.  
Third, I installed new 4mm bolts, they fit very snug in the stock holes, just have to clean the holes up a bit, but you want a tight fit, but not so tight that you can't move the bed up and down.  
I also installed new springs I purchased from Harbor Freight(spring assortment box) to allow for longer length bolts and a tighter bed.

This is a simple e3d v6 mount I quickly threw together for mounting to the standard size end-effector used by the rostock, rostock max, and SeeMeCNC printers. Any other delta that uses the same mounting hole alignment are also compatible.

Designed in Sketchup.

I used 5x M3-1" screws (with matching nuts) to mount the device. Two screws are used horizontally to "clamp" the hotend into the mount, and 3 screws are used to mount the device to the end effector.

Wires are meant to be fed through the hole in the front piece to help reduce strain.

I recently published the little project Nano Pin Protector which provides a shell for the widely used Arduino Nano and its many compatibles.

Now, did you know that instead of using a Nano (which has an 16MHz 8-bit micro-controller with 32KB of flash memory and only 2KB RAM) you could just as well use a Maple Mini module based on an Arm Cortex-M3 STM32 32-bit micro-controller that runs at 72MHz and provides 128KB flash and 20KB RAM memory?

LeafLabs has developed the open source Maple Mini module, which is about the same size as the Arduino Nano and available for about the same price as the Nano. In addition to the original LeafLabs version, there are also several compatible (and cheaper) versions on the market.

Recently, and thanks to Roger Clark, the Maple Mini (and other STM32 controllers) are now supported directly in the Arduino framework. This makes developing for the Maple Mini just as easy (well, almost...) as working with the regular Arduinos.

So, this project generates a similar shell for LeafLabs Maple Mini (or compatible) module which protects all pins from being exposed to accidental shorting with tools or other metallic objects on the work bench.

As a special addition, I found it very useful to have more than just one Gnd and Vcc (3.3V) pin on each side. This facilitates adding several peripherals which need their own ground and maybe 3.3V connection. Thus, in addition to the standard shell that just houses the bare 2x20 pin Maple Mini module, the project also includes versions with 4 or 6 additional pins at the top end. These can be used for adding a tiny 7x2 or 7x3 hole piece of prototype PCB in order to add additional ground and 3.3V pins at the top end of the module, and optionally even two additional LEDs that can be externally connected to any desired output pin.

Right angle pin headers mounted on the upper side of the Maple Mini PCB are used instead of the straight headers normally soldered on the lower side. Two 20-, 22-, or 23-pin single row pin header arrays are needed. This way, all connections to the Maple Mini are horizontal and are safely "hidden" between the upper and lower part of the shell.

The top of the shell has cutout(s) for the LED(s) and integrated RESET and BUT buttons which are printed in-situ and held in position by its waisted shape.

The so covered horizontal pin connector increase the surface of the Maple Mini shell, so that there is enough space on the top shell for a sticker which identifies each pin in a nicely readable size. The stickers contain the basic pin numbers, as well as the additional special uses of the pins. Also, pin capable of pulse width modulation (pw), analog input (ain) and tolerating 5V input (5vt) are indicated on the sticker.

Given that there are several variants of the Maple Mini design which differ just slightly in the placement of the LED and the buttons, their longitudinal position (measured in mm from the USB end of the PCB) is parametrized and can easily adapted as needed.

In addition to the fully parametrized SCAD file, there is also a corresponding PostScript file which generates the labels to stick on the top part of the shell.

The project also includes "read-to-print" STL (3D-objects) and PDF (sticker labels) files for two variants of the Maple Mini:

  • MapleMiniB41B48L26: This version has the buttons at 41/48mm and the LED ad 26.5mm from the USB end. I have tested these with the "Baite" version of the Maple Mini, but it should hopefully also work for the original LeafLabs version (if not, please let me know).
  • MapleMiniB39B46L25: This version has the buttons placed at 39/46mm and the LED at 25mm. It is meant to work with the "other" (non-Baite) compatible version, but it is not (yet) tested. I just guessed the distances from the provided photos, so maybe some finetuning is still needed...

Update 2015-09-07: I have now uploaded new versions of the PDF pin label stickers which also contain the generic GPIO port/bit names in small letters at the very edge of the label. These files have "pb" appended to the file name.

The Maple Mini protector shells were printed from 3mm ABS filament on my DIY Prusa i3 using a 0.4mm nozzle with 0.56mm extrusion width and 0.252 layer height. I print on a clear mirror without Kapton tape but thoroughly cleaned with acetone and double concentrated lemon juice.

Since the two parts of the protective shell hold to each other by a "click"-type mechanism, ABS seems to be the material of choice for this project.

The "E2" versions requires a little 7x2 hole piece of prototype PCB, the "E3" versions a 7x3 hole piece, as shown on the photos. The first row pins are connected to one of the 3.3V pins, the second row pins are connected to one of the GND pins. The LedA/LedB pins of the "E3" version on the third row are connected to small LEDs (check for correct polarity!) and via a current limiting resistor to the GND signal. I use 470R for the red LED and 560R for the green one.
Something to keep next to your battery charger.

title: Floating X mount Prusa i3
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a remix of Auto touch Z end-stop.(https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:220709/) By Radus.

I loved the simplicity of this auto bed leveling

This mount leaves the X axis floating. Two mounts are needed, one for each side. The switches are supposed to be wired in series and firmware set to normally closed switches. When your print head hits the bed, the circuit will be opened and the firmware will register the height.
Remember to set Z safe homing in Marlin since this will need to remove your standard Z

Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER will depend on the amount of backlash when the printer head hits the bed. Opposed to probe auto bed setups, this value is positive. Mine is set to 1.1. Start with a high value (higher than mine), do a first layer test print. Lower it until you see a nice first layer. Starting low might break your printer.

What I did was to incorporate a microswitch from a broken Onkyo reciever instead of the foil Radus has used. See the picture for measurements of the microswitch.
I also made the mount for the original brass nut for Z axis shipped with my printer, instead of the normal nut that Radus is using.

The holes for the wires to the microswitch are quite tight. I used wires from and old LPT cable. An ethernet cable should also be a good source for thin wires.

Drawn in Sketchup, the .skp is there. Feel free to remix!

2016-02-22:
New version uploaded with the possibility to mount the microswitch on either side of the Z-axis rod. As mentibump says in a comment, this design is a bit sensitive to the differences in weight of the X-axis. I plan on converting my printer to bowden and use it with one extruder motor mounted on the X-axis. See this thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:938737
Print with 100% infill and external perimeters first in slic3r. It is a tight fit for the switch.

comments.text:
This is a version of the ROBO 3D R1 Auto Leveling. (See mkelly Thingiverse posts)
The linear nature of the Prusa i3 (Heavy Motor end - Guide & screw rods - Extruder - Guide & screw rods - Light idler end) creates a SEESAW effect. Depending where the Extruder (fulcrum) touches the bed during the G29 sequence the switches open at different rates. Those rates change the results in the Autolevel matrix being not truly reflective of the variations in the bed level. ROBO3D design minimizes this effect.
The other issues in common with ROBO3D are:
If you do a G29 before heating the extruder any solidified filament on the end of the nozzle will alter the true bed position. (When gone after extruder heating).
If you do a G29 after heating extruder the extruder burns a hole in painters tape / Kapton / any low melting point bed material. So again true bed position is different to
Autolevel results.
Method "sort of works" but is not as accurate or hands off as a Capacitive or Inductive sensor.
comments.author: mentibump

author: GuruX

description.text:
Be the envy of the beach with this sand castle kit!

The kit contains:

  • 1 bucket that represents a tower. Perfect to put on the corners of your castle.

  • 1 bucket that represents another tower and it's ideal to combine with the first bucket or to put in the corners too.

  • 1 "Wall-er". The wall-er is the easiest way to make walls. There's also a limiter to create walls with different heights.

  • 1 towers mold. With the towers mold you can add some style to your walls by putting the mold up of the wall.

  • 1 extruder. In the extruder sand and water are combined. With the resulting mixture you can draw on the castle to personalize it.

  • 1 roller. With the roller you can mark the walls to make them more realistic and you can even build some paths!

To create this kit I've used maths concepts such as geometry, proportions, distances... I've also worked with volumes and areas to save the maximum of material when printing!

I hope you'll enjoy it as much as me designing it!

Unlike the MakerBot Replicator Desktop 3D Printer, the printer I built myself is unable to print the kit because the print area is very small.

Comment for any doubt!

title: Rack mount for TP Link SG108

description.text:
So, I'm talking to a friend that came into ownership of a modestly sized server rack to house some racked servers. And it turns out that while his server gear is on a very nice racked and managed switch, the rest of the house is split off and running on typical consumer grade stuff. Or at least that's how I grok'd it.

I asked him how he was managing all the gear? Because lets face it, that type of setup is going to need lots of small boxes. The switch for the house wasn't racked. Well we can't have that!

A little bit of work, and we have this. It's definitely a WIP. It's going to change a lot over time.

The general idea is that you can print just one, or you can print two with one being the mirror image of the other. The two sides can then be joined with a bridge piece and you can pass all your cables through the center.

description.text:
ITALIANO
Ciao, ho creato questo supporto per facilitare lo smontaggio e il rimontaggio del controller della PS4 e della PS3.
In questo modo le levette analogiche non sono più un intralcio.
Il file caricato è leggermente più largo di quello che ho stampato, così dovrebbe aderire meglio al controller.

ENGLISH
Hi, I created this support to make more easier the unmount/mount operation of your PS4/PS3 controller.
In this way the analogic levers are not a problem.
The file .stl uploaded is lightly different from that I printed. It's a bit more larger, so it should be fit better.

your desk has to be 2cm (0.78 inches) thick. I used a thin rubbery tape to generate enough friction to it wont slide.

Wrap your earphones around this device to keep them neat and stop them from tangling in your pocket. Built with a spinning unraveling mechanism to allow for quick and easy access to your earphones.

For best results check out the instruction tab.

For more information read the invention journey at DesignSpark -

http://www.rs-online.com/designspark/electronics/eng/blog/an-engineers-journey-from-unique-concept-to-3d-print

The CAD document (.rsdoc) is attached so you can download and customize it yourself.

The winder was created using DesignSpark Mechanical.

To download the free CAD package click the link below -
http://www.rs-online.com/designspark/electronics/eng/page/mechanical

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PIb_J0MttlU

For best results print vertical with supports and rafts. Once its complete carefully cut away the visible supports using a knife. Twist the two parts then using the knife or sandpaper remove the rest of the remaining supports and bits that could obstruct the spinning. Spin the two pieces back and forth to erode away any internal supports and obstructions in the cavity. After a few twists it will be smooth enough to use with your earphones.

Works well with PLA;
Quality: Standard
Infill: 15%
Temperature: 230 degrees
Duration: <50 minutes.

comments.text: I was thinking - if the shaft went all the way through (which would require the central bulge all the way, but would also probably make the turning smoother), then at the far end, a little wheel, fixed to the wrapping portion, could be set on the axle.  That would allow you to hold the stationary part, fix the headphone jack in the groove, and then run the wheel along the other hand (thumb to finger, for example) to wind the cable up.  That'd result in an easier winding use case, faster than in the video.

The case I designed for a smartwatch built using the excellent Microsoft .Net Micro Framework and an ST Cortex M4 micro controller chip and a sharp memory display.

All electronics and software design was done by the very talented @Justin from http://ingenuitymicro.com/

Links here for more information:-
http://iww.ghielectronics.com/community/forum/topic?id=17105
http://www.ghielectronics.com/community/forum/topic?id=16298
http://www.ghielectronics.com/community/codeshare/entry/954

This is a DesginSpark Mechanical CAD model of my case for the Radius.NET watch as created by @Justin.

DesginSpark Mechanical is available for free and can easily export the files as STL for printing or to Sketchup if you prefer that.

The watch is designed to use a 40mm x 1mm glass and a 18mm watch strap. Both are readily available on ebay. I have found that a UV Glue (as used for attaching smartphone screens to their digitisers works well to attach the glass again available from ebay.

I have printed the case using SLS in Nylon.Most fused filament printers will not have the required resolution to print the part well. EDIT - I just printed this at 0.1mm layer height with 0.4mm nozzle on my Wanhao i3 and it turned out really well using Simplify3D default support.

On mine the holes for the pushers needed drilling with a 4.5mm drill bit and the holes for the strap spring bar needed drilling to 0.8mm (1mm seemed to work for me though).

Note :- this initial version is a bit tight in the Z axis as I didn't leave any tolerance between the display board and the pusher. This means that the back of the case does not sit flush and the buttons do not move as smoothly as I would like.

title: Cartoony Renault Megane
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
3D model of a Renault Megane. Big rims and long bumpers to make it look kinda cartoony and to avoid long bridges. The model is almost empty in the inside in order to save printing time and materials. Rims were retouched sculpting.

Model was printed in a Prusa i2 with a 3mm brim width, layer height of 0.35mm and 0.5mm nozzle. Default size: 10 x 5.6 x 3.6 cm.

Everything was modelled in Blender 2.74. Source files available in the "Thing Files" tab.

Feel free to print, share, modify it under CC license.

title: OpenSCAD Variable Width Text -- TrueType(TTF) Font to DXF Converter

description.text: Come on people! Let's have some variable-width love in the OpenSCAD font arena!   Here is a C program that converts TTF fonts into DXF that is suitable for import and extrusion in OpenSCAD.  Bonus: it includes DIMENSION information that can be used by the dxf_dim OpenSCAD function to layout the text based on character metric information that was in the font.

Take a look at the README... there is a C program that can be compiled with pretty much only freetype2 libraries as a dependency.  This can be used to generate a DXF file that can be used in OpenSCAD.  Take a look at the examples for how to access character metric info.  Maybe someone (hint hint) can adapt the widely used Write.SCAD to use (optionally) this method to lay out characters in various geometries.

comments.text: Note that you need at least OpenSCAD 2014.03 for the provided sample code to run. Under OpenSCAD 2013 it fails to compile. Under 2015, the sample code uses deprecated functions. Here's my alternative code that writes a word:
comments.author: realflash

comments.text:
Nice achievement ! Now we can render any font we want !
Lovely.
comments.author: ErnestoRealize

comments.text:
I have made a custom implementation of this tool here : http://www.trustfm.net/GeneralTools/Font2OpenSCAD.phphttp://www.trustfm.net/General...
Font2OpenSCAD support "multi language" . Let me know your thoughts
comments.author: trustfm

comments.text: hi,
comments.author: nischi

comments.text: I would guess there is a missing glyph in the font that it expects.  Presumably you trying to generate the whole ASCII printable set (that's what the code does by default). Hm... I'll upload an (untested) version that just blindly skips undefined characters. Give that a try and let me know what happens.
comments.author: nischi

CR-7 Extruded

This is a fan housing for a 42mm stepper motor. I installed a direct-drive system to my Ultimaker using Calum Douglas' design. (http://www.calumdouglas.ch/ultimaker-3d-printer/direct-drive-upgrade/). THANKS Calum. Never worry about tightening those short belts again! I decided to add a heatsink and cooling fan to the X and Y steppers. The housing was designed to utilize a 50mm fan, but I ordered 40mm fans by accident, so I designed an adaptor plate that is included as well. I placed a spacer between the stepper and direct-drive mount. The spacers allow for an easy attachment of the fan housing. I had some off-the-shelf spacers that I used, but I've created a model of those too so you don't have to purchase them if you don't have some lying around. My steppers really don't get that hot, but installed a heatsink anyway. The fan housing is large enough for that as well. NOTE: Files names still include "servo", but I really mean stepper. Brain fade!

It's been a while since I printed these, but I think I did 0.2mm layer at 50% fill. It's just a fan housing, so use your own judgement. Insert the (4) spacers and longer screws between the stepper bracket mount and the stepper motor. Attach the fan to the housings next, but leave the screws loose so that the two halves of the housing can open wide enough to snap onto the stepper motor spacers (standoffs). Then install the top screws (M3 x 8mm) and then tighten the fan screws. Calum's website has good documentation for what is required to install the direct drive. For this fan housing installation, you will need (per stepper):
(1) Stepper Fan Housing A
(1) Stepper Fan Housing B
(4) Spacers
(4) M3 x 20mm to 25mm long screws (longer stepper mount screws for use with spacers)
(2) M3 x 8mm screws (top)
(4) M3 x ??mm screws for fan, length depends on your fan
(6) M3 hex nuts
If you use a 40mm fan, then you'll need (1) fan adaptor.

comments.text: Thanks Jelle, yes - I meant stepper motor.  I had servo motors on my mind when I was writing this up.  Corrections made.  I've turned the drivers, and like I mentioned in the description, they don't really get that hot.  I only worry about turning on the fans for prints that take many hours.
comments.author: jwags55

comments.text:
Are you confusing 'servo' with 'stepper motor'? There is a large difference between the two: a servo is a closed loop system (feedback via encoder or potmeter), while the stepper motors on an UM are open loop (overspecced so they should never miss a step).
If your motors are running so hot that you wish to put a fan/heatsink on them, then the first thing to do is to turn down the current to them. If you need that much current without missing steps; you probably have a mechanical problem elsewhere. There is very little precision gained by turning on the current: it is just more heat going into the motors.

description.text:
Updated with new models.

Modern "Claw and ball" foot for furniture (three variations).

  • One file is solid with round sphere bottom
  • The next file has a flat floor surface for stability.
  • The third file has a central mounting hole.

Scale this object to your needs, print out 4 and give them an acetone vapor bath for about 15-20 seconds, then finish the surface with paint. The top part can be inset into a furniture leg and held in place with an inset screw through the center.

  • By the way you can "texture" freshly acetone bathed surface while its still soft.

---- Project notes ---

CAD: Truespace
Art to part time: 50min
Platform: Up!3D ABS, Draft mode, 95% fill
Testing: Easy to de-raft, shape is as designed, inset at top looks good.
Index Arm guide. Support structure needed.

I sculpted this off the top off my head. It's not very detailed by no means. I only spent about 2-3 hours creating it. If you like to see more sculpts from me, please leave a comment. Please do not use this for commercial purposes!

Re-works of a Extruder Mounted Radial Fan to suit the Prusa i3 :

Fan Slide Bracket : Temporary fix for mounting the Cooling Shroud. ( Will be revised later )

Fan Extender arm : Connects between Extruder mount & fan Bracket ...

Radial Fan Bracket : ( TBA ) Still Working on this ...

Radial Fan Cooling Shroud : ( Yet To Complete )

  • Original Round Fan Duct : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:225126
    ( Cooling Duct that works ! )

More to add here later ...

Cheers, Bantum ...

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

New parts & Re-works were mostly done in SketchUp, with continuity check done in netfabb ...

Still working on these :

  • Radial Fan Bracket ...
  • Radial Fan Duct ...

Progress to date : ( Still working on this ... )

  • Print out & mount the Slide extruder bracket : Will need to remove the old fixing point. ( Suggest gluing the slide bracket to front )

Note : There's a possibility of making them one piece later ...

  • Fan Mount Arm : Have test printed it now - may need reworking to suit ...

  • Cooling Shroud : Yet to 're-work' this to fit ...

Cheers, Bantum ...

• Extruder Fan Mount : have moved it to a new page : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1063212

Edits :

  • Trail printed some of the mounting brackets & found they were not quite working, so have added a longer version.

  • Trail printed an Radial Fan Duct but still need more work ( yet to post ) Still working on mounts ...

Ciao, Bantum ...

title: Evolv DNA40 Box Mod - Box Battery

description.text:
A simple box mod (box battery) to use with the Evolv DNA25 or DNA40.
U need:

  • a drip cup (in my sample i used a Svapiamo "easy flat 22 mm" drip cap;
  • negative spring;
  • positive contact;
  • magnets 3x1 and 2x1;
  • DNA40 from Evolv;
  • some cable.
    I attach some variant of body with different drip cap holes and with or without bottom air hole and 3 longs of buttons.

A video about this box (italian):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VbbTIknPH04

To print:

  • i suggest layer 0.15 for body and the two panel;
  • i suggest layer 0.10 and low low (20 mm/sec) per the push buttons.

To mount i suggest to cable the circuit OUT of the box and after u insert in his space.

USE a soft/silicon cable.

title: Printrbot Z Axis 5mm threaded rod upgrade

description.text:
I was unhappy with the 5/16 threaded rod that the Printrbot comes with and the Z-ribbing artifacts.  The problem is the stepper motors have an uneven amount of steps with the 5/16 rod.  When you print something with the 5/16 rod, your layer heights will be off every x number of layers unless you choose very specific layer heights.  By going to 5mm threaded rod(mine cost $15 shipped from McMastercarr) you can change your steps from 2267.72 to an even 4000 steps. This gives a nice even layer height all the way through your print.  Also, by adding dual nuts and a spring, any backlash is excluded.   The other issue is the 5/16 rod coupled to the 5mm motor shaft is a poor design, by using 5mm threaded rod and some tubing, you get an even coupler and no z wobble.  
This is hands down the best upgrade I have done on my printrbot, it improved my prints by a huge amount, if you do any upgrades, this is the one to do, best $15 bucks you will spend.

Print off the parts, one for each side, they will fit perfectly into the stock Printrbot Plus V2.  
Cut the threaded rod to length and install nuts with spring in-between into the new part.  Couple the threaded rod to the motor shafts with a short piece of tubing and zip ties from your local hardware store.  
Adjust your Printrboard firmware in Repitier from the 2267.72 to 4000 steps on the Z-Axis and print!!!  
Also, if you want the best, purchase brass 5mm nuts, however they only come in quantities of 100 from McMasterCarr for $15 so I didn't do this to mine, however, if you want the best possible setup, go with the brass instead of Stainless nuts.

comments.author: FherraZ

comments.text: The pitch is just the distance between the threads.  You need a pitch gauge to measure it, but you can probably measure with a caliper too or just screw a nut that you know the correct pitch of and see if it screws on ok.

When I run 100mm it goes about 130mm. I haven't had time to do a z calibration test piece. I have a Printrbot LC V2, I was actually getting pretty awesome results with everything stock. Any help would be appreciated.
comments.author: theshort

comments.text: Are you positive you got .8 pitch threaded rod? If you have a different pitch, you will have to use a different amount of steps. Almost sounds like you got a pitch of 1.0

comments.author: RedJoe

comments.text: Try a nut you know that is a pitch of .8 and see if it screws on the thread, if so, you know it's correct.  Or use a pitch gauge from your hardware store.

You might have to post over at the printrbot forums and see if you can get some assistance.  It should be 100mm right on the money, it's extremely accurate if things are working correctly.

I printed this in PLA with 30% infill, 205 extruder and 60 heated build plate... came out very strong. I only have a 6x6 build area otherwise i would of printed them larger, but id imagine you can scale this for any size required.
The inside screw holes are a bit hard to get to, but was able to use a flexible screw driver to get them tight.

We had an ant problem and I read about making a sweet-but-deadly mixture involving borax, that ants will think is food and take it back to the colony. It will poison all the ants, including the queen, thus ending your ant problem.

I made this really simple poison holder, which is easy to fill with the deadly liquid, and easy for the ants to get into. And I added a handle, because it's near impossible to pick this thing up without it.

I really didn't need to 3d print something, as there's a lot of household items that will serve this purpose. But it was so simple. Why not?

To make the poison:

1 tbsp borax
3 tbsp sugar
1-2 tbsp hot water
1 tbsp syrup (maple, caramel, etc)

Basically just mix everything together and stir. When it cools down, stir again and pour it in the ant traps and place them near any ant highway. As soon as one ant finds it, it leaves a happy trail that the other ants follow to find it also. Within an hour it will be overflowing with ants. Don't interrupt them, as you want them to suck up the liquid and take it back to the colony. Within a day or two the ants should stop.

The .py file is a SolidPython script that was used to generate the objects (it's a python wrapper around OpenSCAD). I don't expect anyone to use it, but it's included for reference.

author: slavikk

description.text:
Some of the track connectors broke on my grandson's Thomas track so I designed this in OpenSCAD. I am printing a few versions now to see what turns out best.

If you have OpenSCAD the code is parametric so you can change it at will. These versions all generate four connectors at a time but OpenSCAD will allow you to set the number, spacing, etc.

The TrackConnector.stl takes way too long to print with layer height 0.10 and 100% fill. The right file is ThomasConnector-thinbase-close-fa25.stl if you just want something that prints but I recommend using OpenSCAD and generate your own the way you like it.

I sliced the first STL with cura at 0.10 layer height and 100% fill. It takes way too long. More info to follow as I print and experiment.

ThomasConnector.gcode took 5 hours, 18 minutes on my admittedly slow Micro3d. This was layer height of 0.1mm and 100% infill. Both are excessive.

Trying ThomasConnector-thinbase-close-fa15-.15mm-fill33 next.

That file prints much better. I used a layer height of 0.15 and 33% fill. It took 2 hrs 33 min for four pegs.

The best is ThomasConnector-thinbase-close-fa25.stl with a layer height 0f 0.15mm and 25% fill. Cura says it should take an hour but my printer always takes longer.
Make it whatever you want it to be! Designed by Pratt student Jacquelyn Truong.

description.text:
Made this contraption to replace the feeders that comes originaly with the printer. They work alot better then the orginals but they are a work in progress and as such a beta version. Simpler to load the filament and better grip on the filament.

Update : Added files for ver 1.1

Changelog :
1.0 Original design files
1.1 Added rounded corners, Curved the back so that the Cable hole have more clearance especualy for the right feeder is this important. Also added so that the washer isnt needed for the lever anymore and coned the inner block's lower 2 screw holes making it simpler to put in the screws without possibly cracking the outer Shell on the printer. Basecly more clearance. Now it is also possible to use all the original screws without replacing one of them :)

Very special thx to Monza64 for comming with valuable sugestions for the design :)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,21

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Need minor support for the screw holes.

I printed them fairly strait up with 0,21mm and 50 % infill. Had to drill the screw holes a litle but no major thing so the screws went in simpler and wouldnt break the outer Shell of the printer.

Update v1.0: Other then that you need to use the mechanical and screws from the original feeder exept for 1 of the screws that need to be replaced with a slightly longer screw. What you also need todo is to take apart the Wheel lever and remove the screw spacer closest to the screw head and reuse it on the screw that holds the lever arm in the piveting Point.

Update v1.1: You need to take apart the Wheel lever and remove the screw spacer closest to the screw head.

comments.text:
Cinya,
can you give me a hint on the settings of the slicer, just speed, for the flexi stuff? I am trying to get PVA printed.
I will print your extruders today and see over the weekend how it works
comments.author: Cinya

comments.text: Keep the retraction down to a minimum like 0,5mm. I have toyed around with 0 to 1mm. Slow down the support printing speed a great deal and also do not and i can not push this enouph do not raise the temp above 200C keep it under that. I have used for the most between 190 and 195 due to the purolysis effect. Another thing i have learned is that it actually became simpler with a 0,4mm nozzle then the standard 0,35mm one. Donno why but it does, i learned that after i tested it due to i was testing a nozzle i had drilled upp a little extra. My theory is that pva dont like to cramp spaces. To be honest a fine nozzle for supports aint realy a absolute requirement. Have been thinking on drilling up one even more and try what happens then. The feeder have no problems feeding pva it need to push it thru the nozzle also and that is when things can get tricky. Hense my theory on the nozzle size. The reason for the retraction is that you dont want to much melted pva up in the ptfe tube to the collar between the nozzle and the ptfe sins it leaves a oil looking substance behind if you retract it backward more and that can cause a clog looking like burned marchmellow. I use pollysupport also wish is a great compliment it all come down to the item im printing. Reason why i dont use PVA for everything is because it depend on how long PVA will be in retraction waiting for next print use. You do not want to keep PVA to long on hold in the nozzle. For example ... if i do a print and there isnt any support until an hour later into the print. Using PVA is not realy a good idea. I have however when i have done surtain prints made a support pillar on the side of the object. wish is not a bad idea to keep the PVA nozzle alive every layer. Simplify3D makes that extremly simple todo.
comments.author: fvt

comments.text:
WOW... what a great reply!!! RESPECT!
Yes, I was thinking of the pillar and used it with PVA, and I confirm the issue with temperature. I had it down to 185°C at most.
I was using a much more aggressive retraction,3mm but that killed the thing.
How are you handling the extraction of the PVA after the layer was printed, there is much PVA coming out while using the other nozzle already, The pillar may help I guess...
comments.author: Cinya

comments.text: Dont think i know anyone that have printed the feeders with 0,3mm. 0,21mm is probably the most common. Have seen a 0,105mm print. Took aparenly a while to print and i cant realy see the use of a feeder with that layer height.

As I'm sure you are all aware of, using a phillips screwdriver to adjust your Z stop is a pain in the rear.  I created this adjuster so I never have to use a screwdriver again to adjust the Z stop.  It works great, I put an arrow on it so you know where your adjustment is located as well.   This is highly recommended upgrade for your Printrbot V2.

Print out the adjuster. Cut the head off your old 6/32 adjustment long bolt.
Install a 6/32 nut onto the bolt, then thread the bolt into the adjuster at least a 1/4-1/2 inch. Tighten the nut against the adjuster. Screw the knob back into the wooded adjustment shaft and set your Z-stop height. Now you have a nice long adjustment knob that extends up past your X-axis motor for easy adjustment without any tools. Use a permanent marker and add some color to the arrow. I also recommend carefully filing down the threads on the bottom of the bolt where it meets the stop switch, so it's completely even, which means your adjuster will be very accurate in any position.

comments.text: This works awesomely! It took a few tries to get my printrbot calibrated well enough to print the right size but now it works. Also the nut that came with the Z-screw had rubber on the inside so it didn't work with this, but I stole one from the printrbot filament coaster and it works great.
comments.author: jordan314

comments.text: This works very well. But I feel like I should point out that you don't need to cut your screw. All you have to do is put your original screw in upside down. That also leaves you with a nice uniform bottom (the head of the screw) to trigger the z-stop.

title: Sand Flake Castle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Math, symmetry are in nature. The snowflake is symmetrical and playful it permit to teach a child the symmetry.
A snowflake pattern is a clean application to a tessellation.
The snowflake, or rather the water which is the essential component of it, is the element that makes the cohesion of a sand castle.
This mold contrast to the summer temperatures, it is a wink to the past winter. Through this mold, we think to we rehydrate, and why not, eat an ice cream.

The sand flake castle is easily manageable by a child. The structure of flake was strengthened, so that the sand castle does not collapse during the demold step. The design is also thought to be a futuristic fortified castle with its ramparts, its central tower, its door and its defense towers.

The material called "frosted ultra detail plastic" was chosen to see if the mold is filled, and to resemble look like a snowflake.

The material instruction are there:
http://www.shapeways.com/materials/frosted-detail-plastic

The mold max bounding box is L 24 x D 21 x H 12.
The wall thickness is around 0.2 mm.

description.text:
There are enough mouthpieces on Thingiverse so I wanted to create the whole trumpet.  I modeled it off of my own Back Strad dimensions.  The only missing components are the valves which are very tricky to CAD.  If there is legitimate interest in building it then I will work harder on the valves, and make sure everything is printable on a home 3D printer (as it stands, not all components fit).  This was more of a "see if I can CAD a trumpet" experiment.  
Definitely a work in progress.  And happy upload the .sldprt/.sldasm files if people want to work on it.
